content.question:
<math alttext="The figure presents 3 row table, with 7 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “x.” The heading for row 2 is “f prime of x.” The heading for row 3 is “f double prime of x.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. 0 is less than x, which is less than 3. f prime of x is Positive. f double prime of x is Positive. Column 2. x equals 3. f prime of x is Undefined. f double prime of x is Undefined. Column 3. 3 is less than x, which is less than 9. f prime of x is Negative. f double prime of x is Negative. Column 4. x equals 9. f prime of x is negative 3. f double prime of x is 0. Column 5. 9 is less than x, which is less than 11. f prime of x is Negative. f double prime of x is Positive. Column 6. x equals 11. f prime of x is 0. f double prime of x is 0. Column 7. 11 is less than x, which is less than 16. f prime of x is Positive. f double prime of x is Positive." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" columnspacing="0em" columnwidth="3.5em 0.05em 5.5em 5.5em 5.5em 3.5em 5.5em 3.5em 5.5em " equalrows="false" frame="solid" framespacing="0em 0ex" rowlines="solid" rowspacing="0.05em" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mi>x</mi></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>3</mn></mtd><mtd><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>3</mn><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>9</mn></mtd><mtd><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>9</mn><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>11</mn></mtd><mtd><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>11</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>11</mn><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>16</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd></mtd><mtd></mtd><mtd></mtd><mtd></mtd><mtd></mtd><mtd></mtd><mtd></mtd><mtd></mtd><mtd></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mtext>Positive</mtext></mtd><mtd><mtext>Undefined</mtext></mtd><mtd><mtext>Negative</mtext></mtd><mtd><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mrow></mtd><mtd><mtext>Negative</mtext></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mtext>Positive</mtext></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>″</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mtext>Positive</mtext></mtd><mtd><mtext>Undefined</mtext></mtd><mtd><mtext>Negative</mtext></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mtext>Positive</mtext></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mtext>Positive</mtext></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math>
The function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is continuous on the interval <math alttext="open parenthesis, 0 comma 16, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>16</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is twice differentiable except at <math alttext="x equals 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, where the derivatives are undefined. Information about the first and second derivatives of <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for values of <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> in the interval <math alttext="open parenthesis, 0 comma 16, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>16</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is given in the table above. At what values of <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> in the interval <math alttext="open parenthesis, 0 comma 16, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>16</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> does the graph of <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> have a point of inflection?

choices.label: <math alttext="x equals 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="x equals 9" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="x equals 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="x equals 11" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>11</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="x equals 9" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="x equals 11" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>11</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="x equals 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="x equals 9" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

topic.text: 5.8: Sketching Graphs of Functions and Their Derivatives

skill.text: Skill 2.D: Identify how mathematical characteristics or properties of functions are related in different representations.
